Award.AwardTitle: Southern Hemispheric Climate and Carbon Cycle Reponse to Orbital Forcing During the Last ~400,000 Years
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves running a series of transient climate model simulations with an earth system model of intermediate complexity. The goal is to examine the underlying mechanisms of orbitally-paced Pleistocene climate change in the Southern Hemisphere.

Specifically, a global atmosphere-ocean-sea ice model of intermediate complexity, coupled to a vegetation model and a marine carbon cycle model, will be used in the suite of transient climate simulations covering the last four glacial-interglacial cycles. The model will be forced by the history of greenhouse gas concentrations, orbitally-induced changes of solar insolation, and model-based reconstructions of the time evolution of the major glacial ice-sheets.

The researchers will address three issues: i) how greenhouse gas variations and local orbital forcing affect sea-ice extent, climate, and ocean ventilation in the Southern Hemisphere; ii) how sensitive Southern Hemispheric Westerlies are to orbital-scale external forcing; and iii) how the marine carbon cycle responds to orbitally-induced changes in ocean ventilation.

The primary broader impacts involve better modeling of climate and carbon cycling variations over long time periods as well as supporting a female post doctoral scholar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to determine the effects of orbital-scale forcing on the atmosphere, ocean circulation, sea ice and carbon cycle in the Southern Hemisphere.

Variations in atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, ice-sheet extent as well changes in earth’s tilt, wobble and orbit were used as forcings for a transient climate model simulation that covers the climate evolution of the last 8 glacial cycles (784,000 years). This unique simulation, conducted with a 3-dimensional atmosphere-ocean-sea ice-carbon cycle model, reproduces many regional and global features reconstructed from paleo climate records, such as ice cores, ocean and lake sediment cores and cave records.

The transient model simulation has been used to test previously proposed hypotheses on the effects of Southern Hemisphere wind changes on ocean circulation and the global carbon cycle. According to the numerical experiments the glacial/interglacial wind-upwelling-CO2 mechanism is not suited to explain the orbital-scale pacing of atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations during glacial terminations.

By including an interactive ice-sheet model, the project documented further that neither changes of incoming solar radiation, nor greenhouse gas forcing alone could trigger the meltdown of Northern Hemisphere ice-sheets during the last glacial termination. However, the synergistic effect of both factors in the model can cause a rapid deglaciation of the Laurentide and Eurasian ice-sheets. This result calls into question the classical astronomical theory of ice ages, which relies only on Northern Hemisphere summer insolation changes.

The last glacial period was punctuated by a series of abrupt climate change events, known as Dansgaard-Oeschger events. Their origin has hitherto remained a mystery.  Through a newly developed modeling method, our project re-created the history of this variability 50,000 years back in time. The results reveal that glacial ice-sheet instabilities and the corresponding freshwater input into the North Atlantic and the subsequent changes of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation were the main drivers for Dansgaard-Oeschger variability. Our model simulations covering this period and accounting both for the effects of ice-sheet instabilities and the slowly varying orbital-scale forcings can reproduce millennial-scale temperature variations reconstructed in Greenland and Antarctic ice cores, shifts in ocean biogeochemistry in the deep Atlantic as well as large-scale reorganizations of hydroclimate patterns in the tropical and subtropical regions. 

The last glacial termination was characterized by a massive input of glacial freshwater into the North Atlantic. The oxygen isotopic composition of this water has been widely used as a paleoceanographic tracer that can help synchronize records from different regions. Oftentimes, the assumption is made that this tracer moves around in a steady ocean circulation field. This assumption breaks down for the glacial termination, which saw on/off switches of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation. Accounting for these dynamical ocean adjustments in a series of tracer release experiments, conducted as part of this project, leads to very different oxygen isotope distributions in the deep ocean. This effect needs to be taken into account in future synchronization efforts of Atlantic and Pacific Ocean sediment records.

To be able to better compare paleo-model simulations, performed as part of this project, with paleo-proxy datasets, it is important to understand whether paleo-records exhibit seasonal biases.
